mods.abstract: Sepia toned photograph, mounted on board, of a triumphal arch surrounded by people on a street in Cuba. The arch is adorned with wreaths, flags, and two portraits of political leaders. The arch reads in Spanish, "Al primer presidente de la República Cubana S. Tomas Estrada Palma el Cuerpo de Bomberos de la Habana 1902." A sign next to the arch reads "24 de Febrero 1895," which commemorates the start date of the Cuban War of Independence.

From 1898 to 1902, in the aftermath of the Spanish-American War, the United States Military occupied Cuba. The period is known as the First Occupation of Cuba. The 1901 Constitution of the Republic of Cuba was adopted with the Platt Amendment, which stipulated eight conditions for the withdrawal of U.S. troops and the protection of Cuba's independence from foreign intervention. On December 31, 1901, Tomás Estrada Palma (1835-1908) was elected as the first President of the Republic of Cuba. Palma resigned on September 28, 1906, leaving Cuba without a leader and opening the door for the Second Occupation of Cuba (Cuban Pacification), which lasted until 1909. A third occupation, the Sugar Intervention, lasted from 1917 to 1922.
